column5: a school or college for special training

• She trained at the Royal Academy of Music.
    • ;

column5: the opportunity or right to use something or to see somebody/something

column5: to provide somebody with a room or place to sleep, live or sit

column5: to travel or go somewhere with somebody/something

column5: to gradually get more and more of something over a period of time

    • ;
  • We have accumulated a great amount of evidence.

column5: correct and true in every detail
column10:
• an accurate description/picture of something
    • ;

    • ;

  • The film is not historically accurate.

  • an accurate prediction/estimate/assessment

  • an accurate representation/portrayal
    • ;
  • scientifically accurate information/data
    • ;
  • reasonably/entirely/fairly accurate
    • ;
  • The cost is an accurate reflection of the quality of our products.

column5: to succeed in reaching a particular goal, status or standard, especially by making an effort for a long time
column10:
• He had finally achieved success.
    • ;
  • They have both achieved great results.
    • ;
  • She has worked hard to achieve her goal.
    • ;
  • to achieve an objective/aim

  • They could not achieve their target of less than 3% inflation.
    • ;
  • The firm has achieved the status of undisputed market leader.
    • ;
  • achieve something through (doing) something Course objectives were achieved through a range of activities.

column5: to accept that something is true
column10:

column5: to gain something by your own efforts, ability or behaviour

    • ;
  • He has acquired a reputation for dishonesty.
    • ;
  • I have recently acquired a taste for olives.

column5: to change your behaviour in order to deal more successfully with a new situation
column10:
• It's amazing how soon you adapt.
    • ;
  • The organisms were forced to adapt in order to survive.
    • ;
  • adapt to something Some animals have a remarkable ability to adapt to changing environments.
    • ;
  • A large organization can be slow to adapt to change
    • ;
  • The company was able to adapt to the conditions and enhance its position.
    • ;
  • We have had to adapt quickly to the new system.
    • ;
  • adapt yourself to something It took him a while to adapt himself to his new surroundings.

column5: enough in quantity, or good enough in quality, for a particular purpose or need
column10:
• They'll need an adequate supply of hot water.
    • ;
  • The room was small but adequate.
    • ;
  • There is a lack of adequate provision for disabled students.
    • ;
  • He didn't give an adequate answer to the question.
    • ;
  • adequate for something The space available is not adequate for our needs.
    • ;
  • adequate to do something training that is adequate to meet the future needs of industry

column5: next to something
column10:
• The planes landed on adjacent runways.
    • ;
  • numbers that are adjacent in the sequence
    • ;
  • adjacent to something Our farm land was adjacent to the river.
    • ;
  • The vineyards of Verzy lie adjacent to those of Verzenay.
    • ;
  • There is a row of houses immediately adjacent to the factory.

column5: to change something slightly to make it more suitable for a new set of conditions or to make it work better
column10:
• adjust something Watch out for sharp bends and adjust your speed accordingly.
    • ;
  • This button is for adjusting the volume.
    • ;
  • The brakes need to be adjusted.
    • ;
  • adjust something to something Adjust your language to the age of your audience.

column5: a fully grown person who is legally responsible for their actions
column10:
• Children must be accompanied by an adult.
    • ;
  • I simply can't believe that responsible adults allowed a child to wander the streets.
    • ;
  • Why can't you two act like civilized adults?
    • ;
  • The obesity rate among adults has actually increased.

column5: a person who supports or speaks in favour of somebody or of a public plan or action
column10:
• advocate for something/somebody an advocate for hospital workers
    • ;
  • advocate of something/somebody a staunch advocate of free speech

column5: to produce a change in somebody/something
column10:

    • ;

column5: a total number or amount made up of smaller amounts that are collected together
column10:
• a record aggregate of 285 points
    • ;
  • The three smaller parties gained an aggregate of 25 per cent of the vote.

column5: money, food, etc. that is sent to help countries in difficult situations
column10:
• humanitarian/food/medical aid
    • ;
  • An extra £10 million in foreign aid has been provided for victims of the earthquake.
    • ;
  • international aid workers

column5: although

column5: to give something officially to somebody/something for a particular purpose

column5: to become different; to make somebody/something different

column5: a thing that you can choose to do or have out of two or more possibilities

    • ;

    • ;
  • to offer/provide an alternative
    • ;
  • alternative to something Does this offer a viable alternative to the existing system?
    • ;

    • ;
  • alternative for somebody This treatment is the only alternative for some patients.

column5: that can be understood in more than one way; having different meanings
column10:
• an ambiguous word/term/statement
    • ;
  • Her account was deliberately ambiguous.

column5: to change a law, document, statement, etc. slightly in order to correct a mistake or to improve it
column10:
• He asked to see the amended version.
    • ;
  • The law has been amended to read as follows:…
    • ;
  • Parliament will vote to amend the constitution.

column5: a comparison of one thing with another thing that has similar features; a feature that is similar
column10:
• analogy (between A and B) The teacher drew an analogy between the human heart and a pump.
    • ;
  • analogy (with something) There are no analogies with any previous legal cases.

column5: to examine the nature or structure of something, especially by separating it into its parts, in order to understand or explain it
column10:
• analyse something The job involves collecting and analysing data.

  • Researchers have analysed the results in detail using specialist software.
    • ;

    • ;

    • ;
  • The first step is to define and analyse the problem.
    • ;

column5: happening or done once every year

    • ;
  • The 12th annual Music Festival runs from Friday 25th to Monday 28th October.
    • ;
  • Funding will be awarded on an annual basis.
    • ;
  • She organized this year's annual Christmas dinner dance.

column5: to expect something
column10:
• anticipate something We don't anticipate any major problems.
    • ;
  • Our anticipated arrival time is 8.30.
    • ;
  • The eagerly anticipated movie will be released next month.
    • ;
  • anticipate doing something They anticipate moving to bigger premises by the end of the year.
    • ;
  • anticipate something doing something I don't anticipate it being a problem.
    • ;
  • anticipate that… We anticipate that sales will rise next year.
    • ;
  • it is anticipated that… It is anticipated that inflation will stabilize at 3 per cent.

column5: easy to see or understand
column10:
• Their devotion was apparent.
    • ;
  • Then, for no apparent reason, the train suddenly stopped.
    • ;

    • ;
  • apparent to somebody that… It soon became apparent to everyone that he couldn't sing.
    • ;
  • apparent that… It's readily apparent that she has a gift for this kind of writing.
    • ;
  • apparent from something No damage was apparent from a brain scan.
    • ;
  • apparent to somebody The consequences of our actions are not immediately apparent to us.

column5: to add something to the end of a piece of writing
column10:
• Footnotes have been appended to the document.
    • ;
  • The principal has the right to append comments to the final report.

column5: to recognize the good qualities of somebody/something

• Over the years he came to appreciate the beauty and tranquillity of the river.

    • ;

column5: a way of dealing with somebody/something; a way of doing or thinking about something such as a problem or a task

  • It was time to take a different approach.
    • ;
  • an alternative/innovative approach

    • ;
  • The approach they were using no longer seemed to work.

column5: suitable, acceptable or correct for the particular circumstances

  • Please debit my Mastercard/Visa/American Express card (delete as appropriate) (= cross out the options that do not apply).

column5: knowing or realizing something
